kpis.description: The debt to equity ratio measures a company's financial leverage by comparing its total liabilities to its shareholders' equity. A higher ratio indicates more debt relative to equity, which may imply higher financial risk.
kpis.formula: debt to equity ratio = total liabilities / shareholders' equity

kpis.description: The interest coverage ratio assesses a company's ability to pay interest on its outstanding debt. It is calculated by dividing earnings before interest and taxes (EBIT) by the interest expenses. A higher ratio indicates better ability to meet interest obligations.
kpis.formula: interest coverage ratio = EBIT / interest expenses

kpis.description: The current ratio measures a company's ability to pay short-term obligations with its short-term assets. It is calculated by dividing current assets by current liabilities. A ratio above 1 indicates that the company has more current assets than current liabilities.
kpis.formula: current ratio = current assets / current liabilities

kpis.description: The regulatory compliance score evaluates how well a company adheres to industry regulations and standards. It is often based on audits, assessments, and compliance checks, and is expressed as a percentage or score.
kpis.formula: regulatory compliance score = (number of compliant items / total number of items assessed) * 100

kpis.description: The cybersecurity incident rate measures the frequency of cybersecurity incidents within a specific period. It helps organizations understand their vulnerability to cyber threats and is typically expressed as the number of incidents per unit of time or per user.
values_need_in_formula: total number of users or time period
kpis.formula: cybersecurity incident rate = number of cybersecurity incidents / total number of users or time period
